floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in these areas.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout  the week.

The Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and Lake Windermere will remain high today, but we do not expect any flooding to properties.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Newby Bridge sluices remain open due to high lake levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.

River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout the week.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the week.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwent Water remain high due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.

Lake levels are expected to remain high throughout the week.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the week keeping lake levels high at the Lodore gauge.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including King's Staith, Queen's Staith and South Esplanade.  Levels are high but are expected to continue falling today, Wednesday 22/11/2023. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Dry weather is now forecast for this week. This Flood Alert is still in force as the Washford River level remains high. As no rainfall is forecast, the level will continue to slowly fall, and no further flooding will occur. There may remain some limited flooding of low-lying land and roads in and around the Washford River. The Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream and Doniford Stream are now back to normal winter base flow levels. 
Please consider the weather conditions and local water levels and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 11am on 22/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high on the Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham due to rainfall over the weekend. The area most at risk is around Properties around King St, Northgate, Dunswell Rd and North Moor Ln. We expect levels to remain high today, Wednesday 22/11/2023 . Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 8pm on 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 8pm on 22/11/23 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Cae Howel river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Actual peak:- Llanymynech 4.0 m overnight Sunday. 

The forecast is mainly dry with drizzle and showers possible over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 2/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Lower Avon and tributaries. 

Flooding is possible for: Tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.    

Be prepared.

 River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes. 

To check the latest information for your area

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have fallen on the tidal Ouse following recent rainfall but levels upstream in York remain high. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. We expect levels to continue to fall in York today, Wednesday 22/11/2023. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Further scattered showers are also forecast for the next few days. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 22 November. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The forecast for today is for dry weather, Wednesday 22 November. Scattered showers are forecast for the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Thursday 23 November, or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar are slowly falling. There has been no rainfall since Monday morning (20/11/2023). This will allow the river to continue recovering. Given the exceptional total of rainfall (380mm) in the last 30 days, the rate of recovery will be very slow. At Alverstone, the level is falling at around 0.7cm per hour. At Sandown, the level is falling by approximately 0.3cm per hour. No further rainfall is currently expected. As a result, no further impacts are expected. This Flood Alert will remain in force until the river level measured at Sandown has fallen to 1.07mAOD. We will continue to monitor the forecast. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 23/11/2023.

No rainfall is forecast for this week up to and including Saturday.  
We continue to monitor river levels and this Flood Alert will be updated by midday on Wednesday 22/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, but is slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. As well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Barnham Rife is also slowly falling. Flood impacts will continue in Bersted. Wednesday 22/11/2023 and Thursday are expected to remain dry. There could be showers on Friday 24/11/2023 but rainfall totals will be low. Water levels should start to reduce, but will remain higher than normal until at least the weekend. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 23/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.73 m and is falling. The drain level is 7.68 m and is slowly falling.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
The weather forecast is for a dry week ahead and pumping will continue at Huish Episcopi to reduce water levels on the Moors.  We will continue to operate the Parrett Flood Relief Channel to evacuate water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 11am on Wednesday 22/11/2023.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at HEPS please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
This Flood Alert has now been removed as the River Yeo at Pen Mill and Ilchester have fallen to normal winter base flow levels. However, considerable water remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors. Flood water continues to impact the road from Langport to Muchelney and a separate Flood Alert remains in force for this area. 
The weather forecast is for a dry week ahead and we continue to operate our pumping stations, and additional temporary pumps, to lower water levels on the Moors when river levels allow. We continue to divert water from the Parrett into the Sowy (Parrett Flood Relief Channel), but this will be reduced to improve drainage around the Sowy River. 
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

The River Lavant remains high, but is slowly falling. Minimal flood impacts are expected which could affect fields, rural roads and gardens between West Dean and Westhampnett. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and possibly access bridges over the river. Flood water could affect gardens and approach properties at The Sadlers, Westhampnett. Wednesday 22/11/2023 and Thursday are expected to remain dry. There could be showers on Friday 24/11/2023 but rainfall totals will be low. Water levels should start to reduce but will remain higher than normal until at least Thursday. Some roads could be affected by flood water. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 11:00 on 23/11/2023.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Leach. Therefore, the risk of further flooding of low lying land is reducing. The outlook is mainly dry today, 21/11/23, and for the coming days. River levels are falling and we expect this to continue. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes.
